[http://www.cable-lynx.net/~nnorway/ Village of New Norway] |footnotes = }} <!-- Infobox ends --> '''New Norway''' is a small rural village located in the central [[prairie]]s of [[Alberta]], [[Canada]]. Named in 1895 and properly established in 1909, it is located on [[Alberta Highway 21|Hwy 21]], approximately 100 kilometres (60 mi) SSE of [[Edmonton, Alberta|Edmonton]] and 22 kilometres (14 mi) SW of [[Camrose, Alberta|Camrose]], the closest major trading center.
With a population of over 300, New Norway is home to a number of small businesses, and provides its inhabitants with an elementary and secondary school, local fire protection, and municipal services.
==Early history== In 1892, travelling first on the newly constructed [[Canadian Pacific Railway]] (CPR) line, the Ole M. Olstad family disembarked in [[Wetaskiwin, Alberta|Wetaskiwin]] and made their way to the [[Duhamel, Alberta|Duhamel]] settlement, which had been established for some years. The family quickly filed [[Homesteading|homestead]]s a few miles south for themselves and several relatives and friends in the United States. In addition they purchased available CPR land for $3.00 per [[acre]] ($7.41/[[hectare|ha]]).
For a time the area was known as the "Olstead District". However, as other [[Norway|Norwegian]] families (along with those of other nationalities) settled in the area, the name changed to '''New Norway''' around 1895. By 1903 the fledgling community had a school, general store, and a [[blacksmith]] shop to its credit.
In the fall of 1909, in anticipation of the new [[Grand Trunk Pacific]] rail line being built nearby, the town was moved (by the use of skids and seven [[oxen]]) to its present location NW-11-45-21-W4 (see [[Dominion Land Survey]]). According to the ''[[Camrose Canadian]]'', the townsite of New Norway was put on sale October 14, 1909, with 14 businesses filing intent to establish within the first month. Commercial lots sold from $100 to $250, and residential lots were priced from $50 to $150.
The first village council was elected on May 9, 1910 with Norman M. Smith, James F. Willows and Evan O. Olstad serving.
==Geography== Nearby communities include: *[[Duhamel, Alberta|Duhamel]] *[[Ferintosh, Alberta|Ferintosh]] *[[Edberg, Alberta|Edberg]] *[[Camrose, Alberta|Camrose]] *[[Wetaskiwin, Alberta|Wetaskiwin]]
==Demographics== In 2006, New Norway had a population of 323 living in 121 [[house|dwellings]], a 10.6% increase from 2001. The village has a land area of {{convert|1.12|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} and a [[population density]] of {{convert|289.7|/km2|/sqmi|abbr=on}}.<ref name=statcan2006>{{Cite web| url= http://www12.statcan.ca/english/census06/data/profiles/community/Details/Page.cfm?Lang=E&Geo1=CSD&Code1=4810008&Geo2=PR&Code2=48&Data=Count&SearchText=New%20Norway&SearchType=Begins&SearchPR=01&B1=All&GeoLevel=&GeoCode=4810008 | title= New Norway - Community Profile | author= Statistics Canada| authorlink= Statistics Canada| year= [[Canada 2006 Census|Census 2006]] | accessdate= 2007-06-08}}</ref>
